Key Support for Rural Hospitals: ACA significantly reduced uncompensated care costs. Between 2013 and 2015 hospitals’ uncompensated care costs decreased by 30%. As hospitals face an influx in coronavirus patients it is critical that they are paid for the treatment they provide.

Medicaid Expansion: ACA helps states expand Medicaid to vulnerable populations. 17 million+ Americans now have coverage through Medicaid expansion. Importantly Medicaid’s funding structure allows funds to increase in response to a public health emergency like coronavirus.

Access to Vaccinations Without Cost Sharing: Once a COVID vaccine is developed ACA will almost certainly cover the coronavirus vaccine without cost-sharing because it requires plans to cover all vaccinations recommended by the CDC’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices

Comprehensive Coverage: The ACA established what are known as “essential health benefits” mandating coverage of services like prescription drugs and hospitalization. Coronavirus testing and treatment are essential health benefits and must be covered by all ACA-compliant plans.

Americans are relying on our health care system now more than ever and the ACA is one of our most critical tools to protect Americans from the consequences of the coronavirus. Yet Trump and Republicans are moving full steam ahead with their lawsuit to repeal it.

☑️Key Support for Rural Hospitals: ACA significantly reduced uncompensated care costs. As hospitals face an influx in coronavirus patients it is critical that they are paid for the treatment they provide.

☑️Medicaid Expansion: Because of ACA states can get additional funding to expand Medicaid to vulnerable populations. 17 million+ have coverage through Medicaid expansion. Importantly Medicaid’s funding structure allows funds to increase in response to emergency like COVID

☑️Access to Vaccinations Without Cost Sharing: Once a COVID vaccine is developed the ACA would cover it without cost-sharing because it requires plans to cover all vaccinations recommended by the CDC’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP).

☑️Comprehensive Coverage: The ACA established what are known as “essential health benefits” such as prescription drugs and hospitalization. Coronavirus testing and treatment are essential health benefits and must be covered by all ACA-compliant plans.

The President's efforts to obstruct American health care have significant consequences for COVID response. As a result of his sabotage of the ACA the uninsured rate has increased every year he has been in office — and millions more Americans are uninsured as a result.

✔️Support for Rural Hospitals: ACA significantly reduced uncompensated care costs. Between 2013 and 2015 hospitals’ uncompensated care costs decreased by 30%. As hospitals prepare for an influx in COVID patients it is critical that they are paid for the treatment they provide.

✔️Medicaid Expansion: ACA provides states more federal money to expand Medicaid to vulnerable populations. 17 million+ Americans now have coverage through Medicaid expansion. Medicaid’s funding structure allows funds to increase in response to health emergency like coronavirus.
✔️Protections for as Many as 133 Million Americans With Preexisting Conditions: Under ACA anyone who contracts COVID will not be subject to future discrimination from insurance companies.

✔️Access to Critical Vaccinations Without Cost Sharing: Once a COVID vaccine is developed the ACA will almost certainly cover the coronavirus vaccine w/o cost-sharing because it requires plans to cover all vaccinations recommended by the CDC.

✔️Comprehensive Coverage: The ACA established what are known as “essential health benefits” such as prescription drugs and hospitalization. Coronavirus testing and treatment are essential health benefits and must be covered by all ACA-compliant plans.

In the midst of a global pandemic the ACA is one of our most critical tools to protect Americans from the consequences of the coronavirus:  ✔️Increased CDC Funding: The ACA established the CDC Prevention and Public Health Fund which helps states prepare for disease outbreaks.
